awd_titl_txt: Linking proton pumping to hydride transfer: mechanism of transhydrogenase
awd_abstract_narration:
One essential feature of all life is the ability to extract energy from the environment and convert it to useful work. Humans, other animals, plants and microbes all share a set of strategies for conserving and converting energy from one form to another. A central element in these strategies is to generate and then utilize an electrical voltage across a membrane. Energy in one form is used to separate positive and negative charges across a membrane, and then this voltage is used to drive a current of ions that is used to do work such as make ATP, expel toxins or concentrate useful molecules. Membrane spanning proteins have evolved to both generate and utilize the voltage across the membrane.  Since protons are the most common ions that are transported across the membrane for these purposes, the measurement of the capacity for work is called the proton motive force. This project is focused on one protein called the transhydrogenase that uses the proton motive force to drive a chemical reaction to form a molecule, NADPH, that is essential for many cellular processes. For example, NADPH is needed for commercial microbial production of fermentation products, and manipulating the amount of transhydrogenase in the organism is one way to increase product yield. The project is aimed at determining the way in which a flux of protons flowing through the transhydrogenase protein from one side of the membrane (electrically positive) to the other (electrically negative) is coupled to driving a chemical reaction at a different location on the protein. The project will involve students at all levels; undergraduates, graduate students, including two women, and postdocs. The highly interdisciplinary scope of the research will allow students to be trained in a broad range of biochemical and biophysical techniques.

This project is devoted to using biochemical and biophysical methods to examine the mechanism by which the membrane transhydrogenase couples hydride transfer from NADH to NADP+ to the proton electrochemical gradient across the membrane. The PI and his collaborators have determined the high-resolution structure of the protein that revealed that one domain of the 3-domain protein can occupy two dramatically different spatial orientations, more or less flipped by 180o.  Based on this structure it can be postulated that in one configuration the substrate binds in a way that opens a proton channel through the membrane from one side only, allowing a histidine buried within the membrane to be protonated. The domain then "flips" and in the second configuration the product is formed by hydride transfer. The domain then flips back to the initial configuration in which the bound product induces the proton channel to open in the opposite direction, allowing proton dissociation.  The model assumes large conformational changes during the catalytic cycle and also proposes a linkage between substrate binding and proton binding.  These hypotheses will be experimentally tested using a combination of molecular biology, biochemistry and biophysical methodologies. NADPH binding to the enzyme will be tested using fluorescence anisotropy measurements. The enzyme will be reconstituted in proteoliposomes to allow the adjustment of the internal and external pH values along with the transmembrane voltage. Conformational dynamics will be examined by using distance-dependent spectroscopic methods using pairs of spin probes (PELDOR) and fluorescent probes (FRET) using modified cysteines placed at various regions in the protein.

por.por_cntn:
Living organisms need to extract the energy from available foods such as sugar and conserve the energy in a form that can be utilized quickly when and where it is needed. The most common way to do this is to use the chemical energy in foods to synthesize ATP. Many enzymes couple the hydrolysis of ATP to useful work within living cells. In respiring aerobic organisms, including humans, the energy extracted from the metabolism of sugar and other foods is first converted to a proton motive force, an electric voltage across a biological membrane. This is done by enzymes that pump protons across the membrane from the inside to the outside. The enzyme that synthesizes ATP, called the ATP synthase, utilizes the energy of the proton motive force by allowing protons to flow back, outside to inside, and convert this electrical energy back into chemical energy (ATP).

There are several enzymes that have evolved mechanisms to interconvert chemical energy and the electrical energy of the proton motive force. This NSF grant was dedicated to examining the mechanism of one of these enzymes called the proton-coupled transhydrogenase. There is a family of closely related enzymes found in mammalian mitochondria as well as in bacteria. In our laboratory we primarily studied the proton-coupled transhydrogenase from the bacterium E. coli, but the mechanisms of the enzymes are the same.

The E. coli proton-coupled transhydrogenase is a membrane protein that is located in the cytoplasmic membrane of the bacterium. The enzyme catalyzes hydride transfer (one proton and two electrons) between metabolites NADH and NADP+ to yield NAD+ and NADPH. The reaction is reversible, Remarkably, this simple biochemical reaction is coupled to moving a proton across the membrane. When run in the forward direction to yield NADPH as a product, hydride transfer must accompany one proton moving from the outside of the cell to the inside. This utilizes the energy of the proton motive force to increase the concentration of NADPH which is important to eliminate potentially damaging reactive oxygen species.  When the reaction is run in the reverse direction to yield NADH as a product, the hydride transfer is coupled to moving a proton from the inside ot the cell to the outside, thus generating a proton motive force. The resulting proton motive force can then be uttilized by the ATP synthase to make ATP.  Using purified transhydrogenase and ATP synthase enzymes, we demonstrated this reaction in reconstituted proteoliposomes.

The mechanism of the E. coli proton-coupled transhydrogenase was examined by two methods. 

1. HDX-MS (hydrogen-deuterium exchange monitored by mass spectrometry).

2. Cryo-electron microscopy.

Both methods clearly demonstrated large conformational changes of the transhydrogenase due to the binding of NADP+ and the binding of NADPH. The binding of these ligands to the enzyme in one part of the enzyme resulting in large conformational changes that alter the conformation of the channel that facilitates proton transfer across the membrane. In one conformation, a protonatable histidine residue is exposed to the outside aqueous phase and in the second conformation, the histidine is exposed to the inside or cytoplasmic aqueous phase. 

The mechanism supported by these changes is consistent with previous studies both by our group and by others. The binding of the substrate/product result in alternate exposure of the histidine in the proton channel to opposite sides of the membrane. Hence, the histidine can bind to a proton originating from one side of the membrane and then release the proton on the opposite side. 

The work accomplished confirms a unique mechanism by which chemical and electrical energy can be interconverted. Other enzymes utilize totally different mechanisms to accomplish this energy interconversion.

These studies were performed by two postdoctoral research associates whose professional training was furthered. One of the postdocs took a job with Abbott Labs after completing this work and now works in the pharmaceutical industry engaged in studies involving COVID.
